page.title: List of accidents and incidents involving airliners in the United States

revisions.rev:
{{TOCright}} This '''list of accidents and incidents on airliners in the United States''' summarizes airline accidents that occurred within the territories claimed by the [[United States]], with information on airline company with flight number, date, and cause.
This list is a subset of the '''[[list of accidents and incidents involving airliners by location]]'''.
It is also available grouped * by year as [[List of accidents and incidents involving commercial aircraft]]; * [[List of accidents and incidents involving airliners by airline|by airline]]; * [[:Category:Accidents and incidents involving airliners|in alphabetical order]].
''This list is dynamic and by no means complete!''
For alternative, more exhaustive lists, see: * [http://www.baaa-acro.com/ Aircraft Crash Record Office] or * [http://www.aviation-safety.net/ Aviation Safety Network].
== Alabama == * '''[[Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 2254]]''' collided with a [[Civil Air Patrol]] [[Cessna 172]] over [[Gadsden, Alabama]] on April 9, 1990. Both individuals on board the Cessna were killed, while Flight 2254 was able to land safely at [[Northeast Alabama Regional Airport]].<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1990). [http://www.ntsb.gov/ntsb/GenPDF.asp?id=ATL90FA095A&rpt=fi Factual Report]. (PDF.) Accessed December 06, 2010.</ref>
* '''[[GP Express Flight 861]]''' crashed in [[Anniston, Alabama]] on June 8, 1992 after the crew lost spatial and situational awareness while attempting to land. Two passengers and the captain were killed.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1993). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR93-03.pdf Controlled Collision with Terrain; GP Express Airlines Flight 861; Beechcraft C99 N118GP; Anniston, Alabama; June 8, 1992]. (PDF). Retrieved December 06, 2010.</ref>
* '''[[L'Express Airlines Flight 508]]''' crashed in [[Birmingham, Alabama]] while attempting to land at [[Birmingham Municipal Airport]] during a severe thunderstorm on July 10, 1991, killing 13 people.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1992). [http://www.airdisaster.com/reports/ntsb/AAR92-01.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: L'Express Airlines, Inc., Flight 508; Beech C99, N7217L; Weather Encounter and Crash, Near Birmingham, Alabama; July 10, 1991]. (PDF.) Retrieved December 06, 2010.</ref> It remains the deadliest commercial aviation accident in Alabama history.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19910710-0|title=L'Express Airlines Flight 508}}</ref>
* '''[[Pennsylvania Central Airlines Flight 105]]''' crashed while attempting to land at [[Birmingham Municipal Airport]] on January 6, 1946. The three pilots were fatally wounded. The accident is the only fatal accident recorded at Birmingham airport.
==Alaska== * '''[[Alaska Airlines Flight 1866]]''' crashed into a mountain near [[Juneau, Alaska]] on September 4, 1971, killing all 111 on board.<ref>CNN Transcript. [http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0002/01/bn.02.html Breaking News. Alaska Airlines Flight 261: Plane Plummets Into Pacific; 88 People on Board; Armada of Boats Searching for Signs of Life]. Aired February 1, 2000. Available at [http://www.cnn.com http://www.cnn.com]. Accessed on May 25, 2009.</ref> It was the first fatal jet airliner crash for [[Alaska Airlines]], and the worst plane crash in the history of the United States until [[Eastern Air Lines Flight 66|June 24, 1975]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historylink.org/index.cfm?DisplayPage=output.cfm&File_Id=2107|title=HistoryLink.org - the Free Online Encyclopedia of Washington State History|accessdate=2009-05-25}}</ref>
* '''[[KLM Flight 867]]''' lost all four engines after flying through [[volcanic ash]], but managed to land safely and without loss of life at [[Anchorage International Airport]] on December 15, 1989.
* '''[[Northwest Airlines Flight 4422]]''' crashed into [[Mount Sanford (Alaska)|Mount Sanford]] killing all 30 on board on March 12, 1948.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Mummified remains from 1948 plane crash identified |url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5iXzfG6IVpd4OfkdxnQfGJVk-8m7QD92JQEK00 |quote=Nine years of sleuthing, advanced DNA science and cutting-edge forensic techniques have finally put a name to a mummified hand and arm found in an Alaska glacier. The remains belong to Francis Joseph Van Zandt, a 36-year-old merchant marine from Roanoke, Va., who was on a plane rumored to contain a cargo of gold when it smashed into the side of a mountain 60 years ago. Thirty people died in the crash. |agency=Associated Press |date=August 17, 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-18 }}</ref> The wreckage was lost for nearly fifty years until being located in 1997. The exact cause of the accident was never determined.
* '''[[Wien Air Alaska Flight 99]]''' crashed into Sevuokuk Mountain while on approach to [[Gambell, Alaska]] through heavy fog on August 30, 1975. 10 people on board were killed on impact and in the subsequent fire.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1976). [http://www.airdisaster.com/reports/ntsb/AAR76-01.pdf Wien Air Alaska Fairchild F-27B, N4904, Gambell, St. Lawrence, Alaska, August 30, 1975]. Retrieved December 06, 2010.</ref>
* '''[[Wien Consolidated Airlines Flight 55]]''' crashed into [[Pedro Bay]], killing all 39 on board on December 2, 1968 after encountering extreme air turbulence and suffering structural failure.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1970). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR70-16.pdf "Aircraft Accident Report: Wien Consolidated Airlines, Inc.; Fairchild F-27B, N4905; Pedro Bay, Alaska; December 2, 1968".]. Retrieved September 02, 2009.</ref> The accident is the third-worst accident involving a [[Fairchild F-27]].<ref>{{ASN accident|id = 19681202-0|type = Accident|accessdate = 2009-09-02}}</ref>
==Arizona== * '''[[Grand Canyon Airlines Flight 6]]''' collided with a [[Bell 206]] helicopter over [[Grand Canyon National Park]] on June 18, 1986. All 25 passengers and crew on board the two aircraft were killed.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1987). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR87-03.pdf Grand Canyon Airlines, Inc., and Helitech, Inc., Midair Collision Over Grand Canyon National Park, June 18, 1986]. (PDF.) Retrieved December 06, 2010.</ref>
* [[United Airlines]] Flight 718 and [[TWA]] Flight 2 '''[[1956 Grand Canyon mid-air collision|collide over the Grand Canyon]]''' on June 30, 1956, killing all 128 aboard both aircraft. A Civil Aeronautics Board investigation determined that the aircraft had been flying in each others' [[blind spot (vehicle)|blind spot]]s and did not see each other prior to impact.<ref>[[Civil Aeronautics Board]]. Docket #SA-320. File #1-0090. April 17, 1957. [http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?file&fn=8&name=*S%3A%5CDOT_56GB%5Cairplane%20accidents%5Cwebsearch%5C063056.pdf pdf]. [[US Department of Transportation]]. Accessed online on May 25, 2009.</ref>
==Arkansas==<!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[American Airlines Flight 1420]]''' overran the runway while attempting to land at [[Little Rock National Airport]] on June 1, 1999. The pilots decided to land though heavy winds and [[wind shear]] exceeded the safety limits for the aircraft, and in their rush to land they made a number of critical errors that led to the flight's crash. The captain and ten passengers were killed on impact.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (2001). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/2001/AAR0102.htm "Aircraft Accident Report: Runway Overrun During Landing; American Airlines Flight 1420; McDonnell Douglas MD-82, N215AA; Little Rock, Arkansas; 1 June 1999".]. Retrieved December 23, 2005.</ref>
* '''[[Texas International Airlines Flight 655]]''' crashed into [[Black Fork Mountain]] on September 27, 1973, killing all 8 passengers and 3 crewmembers. The pilots had descended below the minimum altitude for the area while attempting to circumnavigate a thunderstorm.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1974). [http://www.airdisaster.com/reports/ntsb/AAR74-04.pdf "Aircraft Accident Report: Texas International Airlines, Inc; Convair 600, N94230; Mena, Arkansas; September 27, 1973".] Retrieved May 25, 2009.</ref>
==California== [[File:AeromÃ©xico498.jpg|right|thumb|[[AeromÃ©xico Flight 498]] falling to the ground immediately after colliding with a Piper Archer.]] [[File:JetBlue292Landing.jpg|right|thumb|[[JetBlue Airways Flight 292]] executes an emergency landing after its nose gear locked in an irregular position.]] <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * 75 passengers on board '''[[AerolÃ­neas Argentinas Flight 386]]''' fell ill with [[cholera]] after eating contaminated shrimp on {{date|February 20, 1992}} between [[Lima, Peru]] and [[Los Angeles]]. One person died.<ref>Mydans, Seth. "[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE3D9133BF932A15751C0A964958260&n=Top/News/Health/Diseases,%20Conditions,%20and%20Health%20Topics/Cholera Cholera Kills One and Fells Many on Flight]." ''[[The New York Times]]''. Friday February 21, 1992. Retrieved on June 15, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[AeromÃ©xico Flight 498]]''' collided with a [[Piper Cherokee|Piper Archer]] on August 31, 1986. All 64 people on both aircraft were killed. The stricken aircraft plummeted into [[Cerritos, California]], killing an additional 15 on the ground.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1987). [http://www.airdisaster.com/reports/ntsb/AAR87-07.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Collision of Aeronaves de Mexico, S.A.; McDonnell Douglas DC-9-32, XA-JED and Piper PA-28-181, N4891F; Cerritos, California; August 31, 1986]. Retrieved on May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Alaska Airlines Flight 261]]''' went down on January 31, 2000 in the [[Pacific Ocean]] about {{convert|2.7|mi|km}} north of [[Anacapa Island, California]]. The two pilots, three cabin crew members, and 83 passengers on board were killed, and the aircraft was destroyed.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (2002). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/2002/AAR0201.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Loss of Control and Impact with Pacific Ocean; Alaska Airlines Flight 261; McDonnell Douglas MD-83, N963AS; About 2.7 Miles North of Anacapa Island, California; January 31, 2000]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[American Airlines Flight 28]]''' collided with a [[US Army Air Corps]] [[Lockheed Ventura B-34 Lexington|B-34]] [[bomber]] over [[Chino Canyon]] after the army pilot's reckless flying severed the airliner's tail. All twelve on board Flight 28 were killed; both army pilots survived.<ref>[[Civil Aeronautics Board]]. Docket #SA-74. File #2362-43. January 28, 1943. [http://ntl1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=135%22 html]. [[US Department of Transportation]]. Accessed online on September 8, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[BCPA Flight 304]]''' crashed during its initial approach towards [[San Francisco International Airport]] on October 29, 1953, killing all 19 people on board, including the American pianist [[William Kapell]]<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = British Commonwealth Pacific Airlines, LTd., Near Half Moon Bay, California, October 29, 1953 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = April 12, 1954 | id = File No. F-112-53 | url = http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/BCPA_Flight_304_accident_investigation_report | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
* '''[[Flying Tiger Line Flight 282]]''' crashed near the top of Sweeney Ridge in [[San Bruno]] on December 24, 1964.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = The Flying Tiger Line Inc. L-1049H, N6915C, San Francisco International Airport, San Francisco, California, December 24, 1964 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = June 8, 1966 | id = File No. 1-0064 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=778%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
* '''[[Golden West Airlines Flight 261]]''' collided in mid-air with a Cessna 150 (N11421) near [[Whittier, California]] on January 9, 1975.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1975). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR75-14.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Golden West Airlines, Inc. De Havilland DHC-6, N6383, and CessnAir Aviation, Inc., Cessna 150, N11421, Whittier, California, January 9, 1975]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Hawthorne Nevada Airlines Flight 708]]''' crashed into the tallest mountain in the [[Continental United States]], [[Mount Whitney]], near [[Lone Pine, California|Lone Pine]], on February 18, 1969, killing all 35 passengers and crew on board.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1970). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR70-05.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Mineral County Airlines d.b.a Hawthorn Nevada Airlines; DC-3, N15570; Near Lone Pine, California; February 18, 1969]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Hughes Airwest Flight 706]]''' collided with a [[fighter jet]] on June 6, 1971, and crashed into the [[San Gabriel Mountains]] near [[Duarte, California]], killing all 49 people aboard.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1972). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR72-26.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Hughes Air West DC-9, N9345; and U.S. Marine Corps F-4B, 151458; Near Duarte, California; June 6, 1971]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Japan Airlines Flight 2]]''' accidentally landed in [[San Francisco Bay]] while attempting to land at [[San Francisco International Airport]] during heavy fog on November 22, 1968.
* '''[[JetBlue Airways Flight 292]]''' executed an emergency landing on September 21, 2005 in [[Los Angeles International Airport]] after the nose wheels of the landing gear jammed in an abnormal position. No one was injured.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/sep/22/local/me-jetblue22|title=Disabled Airliner Creates a 3-Hour Drama in Skies|last=Morin|first=Monte|coauthors=Stuart Pfeifer, Megan Garvey|date=September 22, 2003|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=2008-08-05}}</ref>
* '''[[Pacific Air Lines Flight 773]]''' crashed near [[San Ramon, California]] on May 7, 1964 after a passenger shot the flight crew and killed himself, causing the plane to crash and killing all 44 on board.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19640507-0|title=Pacific Air Lines Flight 773|accessdate=2009-05-26}}</ref>
* '''[[Pan Am Flight 7]]''' crashed into the [[Pacific Ocean]] while en route to Hawaii on November 8, 1957, killing all on board. The reason for the crash was never determined.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Pan American World Airways, Inc., Boeing 377 N90944, In the Pacific Ocean, Between Honolulu and San Francisco, November 9, 1957 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = January 14, 1959 | id = File No. 1-00 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=653%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
* '''[[Pan Am Flight 845]]''' struck the Approach Light Structure (ALS) navigational aids at the end of [[San Francisco International Airport]]'s runway 01R on takeoff for [[Tokyo]] on July 30, 1971.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1972). [http://www.airdisaster.com/reports/ntsb/AAR72-17.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Pan American World Airways; Boeing 747, N747PA; Flight 845; San Francisco, California; July 30, 1971]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Pan Am Flight 1104]]''' crashed into a mountain near [[Boonville, California]] on January 21, 1943, killing all on board, including [[Rear-Admiral]] [[Robert Henry English]], Commander of the [[ComSubPac|U.S. Pacific Submarine Fleet]].<ref>{{cite conference | title = Report of the Civil Aeronautics Board | booktitle = | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = June 18, 1943 | id = File No. 1413-43 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=140%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
* '''[[PSA Flight 182]]''' collided with a [[Cessna]] over [[San Diego]] on September 25, 1978, killing all 144 people on both aircraft. It is the deadliest aircraft disaster in California history, the first fatal Pacific Southwest Airlines incident, and, at the time, the deadliest aircraft incident in the United States.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1979). [http://www.psa-history.org/museum/NTSBAAR7905.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Pacific Southwest Airlines, Inc., B-727, N533PS and; Gibbs Flite Center, Inc., Cessna 172, N7711G; San Diego, California; September 25, 1978]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[PSA Flight 1771]]''' crashed near [[Cayucos, California]] on December 7, 1987 after being hijacked and by a disgruntled former airline employee.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1989). [http://www.ntsb.gov/NTSB/brief.asp?ev_id=20001213X32679&key=1 NTSB Brief: Pacific Southwest Airlines Flight 1771]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Scandinavian Airlines Flight 933]]''' crashed in [[Santa Monica Bay]], approximately {{convert|6|nmi|km}} west of the [[Los Angeles International Airport]] on January 13, 1969.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1970). [http://www.airdisaster.com/reports/ntsb/AAR70-14.pdf Aviation Accident Report: Scandinavian Airlines System; McDonnel-Douglas DC-8-62, LNM00 (Norwegian Registry); In Santa Monica Bay, Near Los Angeles, California; January 13, 1969]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Southwest Airlines Flight 1455]]''' overran the runway upon landing at [[Burbank-Glendale-Pasadena Airport]] on March 5, 2000.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (2002). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/2002/AAB0204.pdf Aviation Accident Brief: Southwest Airlines flight 1455]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[USAir Flight 1493]]''' collided while attempting to land with a plane attempting to take off on the same runway in [[Los Angeles, California]] on February 1, 1991.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1991). [http://www.airdisaster.com/reports/ntsb/AAR91-08.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Runway Collision of USAir Flight 1493, Boeing 737; and SkyWest Flight 5569 Fairchild Metroliner; Los Angeles International Airport, Los Angeles, California; February 1, 1991.]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Newhall Crash|United Airlines Trip 34]]''' crashed into Rice Canyon, [[California]] on December 27, 1936, killing all 12 passengers and crew.
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 266]]''' crashed into [[Santa Monica Bay]] four minutes after takeoff on January 18, 1969.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1970). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR70-06.pdf United Air Lines, Inc.; Boeing 727-22C, N7434U; Near Los Angeles, California; January 18, 1969]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 615]]''' crashed into mountainous terrain {{convert|15|mi|km}} southeast of [[Oakland]], careened into [[Tolman Peak]] and over its knoll, scattering on the downslope and into [[Dry Gulch Canyon]] below in a fiery explosion August 24, 1951. All 50 persons on board perished.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = United Air Lines, Inc., Near Oakland, California, August 24, 1951 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = March 12, 1952 | id = File No. 1-0058 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=488%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
* '''[[Western Air Express Flight 7]]''' crashed into Pinetos Peak northeast of [[San Fernando, California|San Fernando]] on January 12, 1937, killing five, including adventurer and documentary filmmaker Martin Johnson of [[Martin and Osa Johnson]] fame.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Report of the Accident Board | booktitle = | publisher = Accident Board of the Bureau of Air Commerce | date = May 12, 1937 | id = | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=61%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
* A [[TWA]] [[Douglas DC-2]] '''[[1938 Yosemite TWA crash|crashed]]''' into [[Yosemite National Park]] while attempting to divert to [[Fresno]] during severe weather on {{date|March 1, 1938}}.<ref>{{cite news | author = Source: UP | title = U. S. names Air Crash Probe Board. Bodies of Nine Dead are Brought to Fresno from Yosemite Peak. | work = The Fresno Bee Republican | place = [[Fresno, California]] | date = June 14, 1938 | url = http://www3.gendisasters.com/california/12691/yosemite-national-park-ca-airliner-crash-mar-1938 | accessdate = 2009-05-24}} </ref>
==Colorado== * A chartered Avjet [[Gulfstream III]] [[business jet]] '''[[2001 Avjet Aspen crash|crashed]]''' into terrain while on instrument approach to [[Aspen-Pitkin County Airport]], [[Aspen, Colorado]], killing all 18 on board.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (2002). [http://www.ntsb.gov/Publictn/2002/AAB0203.pdf Aircraft Accident Brief: Avject Corporation; Gulfstream III, N303GA; Aspen, Colorado; March 29, 2001]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Continental Airlines Flight 1404]]''' crashed while taking off from [[Denver]] on December 20, 2008, resulting in 2 critical injuries and 36 non-critical injuries. The aircraft was written off.<ref>Wyatt, Kirsten. "[http://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/20081221167017/wire/world-news/passengers-flee-burning-jet-in-denver-investigation-underway.html Firefighter says it's a 'miracle' no one died in Denver burning jet]." ''[[Associated Press]]''. Sunday December 21, 2008.</ref>
* '''[[Continental Airlines Flight 1713]]''' crashed on take-off in a snowstorm from the [[Denver, Colorado]] Stapleton International Airport on November 1, 1987. The crash resulted in the deaths of 28 of the aircraft's occupants while 54 survived. The airplane was destined for [[Boise, Idaho]].<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1988). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR88-09.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Continental Airlines, Inc., Flight 1713; McDonnel Douglas DC-9-14, N626TX; Stapleton International Airport; Denver, Colorado; November 15, 1987]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 585]]''' crashed while attempting to land at [[Colorado Springs Airport]] on March 3, 1991<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1992). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR92-06.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: United Airlines Flight 585; Boeing 737-291, N999UA; Uncontrolled Collision with Terrain for Undetermined Reasons; 4 miles South of Colorado Springs Municipal Airport; Colorado Springs, Colorado; March 3, 1991]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 610]]''' crashed near [[Denver]] on June 30, 1951 killing all 50 people on board.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = United Airlines, Inc., - Fort Collins, Colorado, June 30, 1951 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = December 7, 1951 | id = File No. 1-0050 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=486%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 629]]''' exploded over [[Longmont, Colorado]] on November 1, 1955 due to a bomb placed on the aircraft by [[John Gilbert Graham]] as part of an attempt to collect [[insurance fraud|insurance money]].<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = United Airlines, Inc., Douglas DC-6B, N. 37559, Near Longmont, Colorado, November 1, 1955 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = May 10, 1956 | id = File No. 1-0143 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=607%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 663]]''' was the location of a "minor international incident" on April 7, 2010 involving a [[Qatar]]i diplomat on the leg of a [[United Airlines]] flight from [[Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport]] to [[Denver International Airport]]. The diplomat prompted a mid-air [[terrorism]] alert after smoking in the airplane lavatory, which led the Qatari government to recall him two days later.
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 859]]''' crashed during landing at [[Stapleton International Airport]], [[Denver, Colorado]] on July 11, 1961. The aircraft slammed into several airport vehicles, including construction equipment, and caught fire, killing 18 (including one on the ground) and injuring 104 from a total of 122 people on board.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = United Airlines, Inc., Douglas DC-8, N 8040U, Stapleton Airfield, Denver, Colorado, July 11, 1961 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = July 16, 1962 | id = File No. 1-0003 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=725%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
==Connecticut== <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[American Airlines Flight 1572]]''' crashed while attempting to land at [[Bradley International Airport]] due to incorrect altimeter setting, on November 12, 1995.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1996). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/1996/AAR9605.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Collision with Trees On Final Approach; American Airlines Flight 1572; Mcdonnell Douglas; Md-83, N566Aa; East Granby, Connecticut; November 12, 1995]. Retrieved May 25, 2009.</ref>
==District of Columbia== [[File:Af90.jpg|right|thumb|[[Air Florida Flight 90]] submerged in the [[Potomac River]].]] * '''[[Air Florida Flight 90]]''' crashed in [[Potomac River]] in 1982 after hitting [[14th Street Bridge (Potomac River)|14th Street Bridge]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] shortly after takeoff from [[Washington National Airport]] in [[Arlington County, Virginia]], during icy conditions. The captain declined to de-ice the aircraft after waiting on the runway for nearly an hour, causing a fatal buildup of ice on the wings.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1982). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR82-08.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Air Florida, Inc; Boeing 727-222, N62AF; Collision with 14th Street Bridge, Near Washington National Airport, Washington, D.C.; January 13, 1982]. Retrieved May 25, 2009.</ref> Four passengers and a [[flight attendant]] survive.
* '''[[Eastern Air Lines Flight 537]]''' collided with a [[Lockheed P-38 Lightning]] on November 1, 1949, killing all but the P-38 pilot.<ref>[[Civil Aeronautics Board]]. Docket #SA-202. File #1-0138. [http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=447%22 Department of Transportation Special Collections]. September 26, 1950. Retrieved May 25, 2009.</ref>
==Florida== [[File:DAL1288a.jpg|right|thumb|The engine of [[Delta Air Lines Flight 1288]] after it experienced catastrophic turbine failure on July 6, 1996.]] * [[Airborne Transport]] [[airliner]] '''''[[NC16002 disappearance|NC16002]]''''' disappeared the night of December 28, 1948 near the end of a scheduled flight from [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]] to [[Miami, Florida]]. The aircraft was never found, and the case remains unsolved.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = Airborne Transport, Inc. -- Miami, Florida, December 28, 1948 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = July 15, 1949 | id = Docket No. SA-183, File No. 1-0118 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=423%22 | accessdate = 2010-12-05 }}</ref>
* '''[[America West Flight 556]]''' was ordered back to terminal after pilots were suspected of being drunk on {{date|July 1, 2002}}.<ref>{{cite news |first= Deborah|last=Sharp | author2 = Marilyn Adams |title= America West pilots arrested for being legally drunk|url= http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2002/07/01/amwest-pilots.htm|newspaper= USA Today|publisher= |date=2002-07-02 |accessdate=2009-09-08}}</ref>
* '''[[Chalk's Ocean Airways Flight 101]]''' crashed off [[Miami Beach, Florida]] due to [[structural failure]], December 19, 2005.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (2007). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/2007/AAR0704.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: In-flight Separation of Right Wing Flying Boat, Inc., doing business as Chalkâs Ocean Airways Flight 101 Grumman Turbo Mallard G-73T, N2969 Port of Miami, Florida December 19, 2005]. Retrieved May 26, 2009</ref>
* '''[[Comair Flight 5054]]''' experienced severe icing conditions resulting in a rapid loss of altitude on March 19, 2001. The crew was able to recover control of the aircraft and made a successful emergency landing at [[West Palm Beach Airport]].
* '''[[Cubana de AviaciÃ³n Flight 493]]''' collided with a [[US Navy]] [[Beechcraft Model 18|Beechcraft SNB-1 Kansan]] on April 25, 1951, killing all on both aircraft.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = Compania Cubana de Aviacion, S.A. and U.S. Navy, Key West, Florida, April 25, 1951 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = October 17, 1951 | id = File No. F-104-51 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=482%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
* '''[[Delta Air Lines Flight 1288]]''' experienced an uncontained, catastrophic turbine engine failure during takeoff at [[Pensacola]] on July 6, 1996. Debris from the front compressor hub of the engine penetrated the fuselage, killing two passengers.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1998). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/1998/AAR9801.pdf Uncontained Engine Failure Delta Air Lines Flight 1288 McDonnell Douglas MD-88, N927DA Pensacola, Florida July 6, 1996]. Retrieved May 26, 2009</ref>
* '''[[Eastern Air Lines Flight 346]]''' crashed and burned while landing at [[Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport]] on May 18, 1972.
* '''[[Eastern Air Lines Flight 401]]''' crashed into the [[Everglades]] on December 29, 1972 while attempting to land in [[Miami, Florida]].<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1973). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR73-14.pdf Aircraft accident report: Eastern Air Lines, Inc., L-1011, N310EA, Miami, Florida, December 29, 1972]. Retrieved May 26, 2009</ref>
* '''[[Eastern Air Lines Flight 855]]''' lost three engines but managed to land safely at [[Miami International Airport]] on May 5, 1980.
* '''[[National Airlines Flight 16]]''' crashed into the water after overshooting the runway in [[Lakeland, Florida]] on October 5, 1945. Two passengers drowned.
* '''[[National Airlines Flight 193]]''' crashed into [[Escambia Bay]], sinking in {{convert|12|ft|m}} of water, on May 8, 1978 due to heavy fog. Three passengers drowned while attempting to exit the aircraft.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1978). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR78-13.pdf Aircraft accident report: National Airlines, Inc., Boeing 727- 235, N4744NA, Escambia Bay, Pensacola, Florida, May 8, 1978 / National Transportation Safety Board]. Retrieved May 26, 2009</ref>
* '''[[Northwest Airlines Flight 5]]''' suffered an in-flight engine failure due to improper maintenance procedures on January 4, 1990. The engine separated from the wing and landed in a field near [[Madison, Florida]].
* '''[[Northwest Orient Airlines Flight 705]]''' broke up in midair and crashed into [[the Everglades]] shortly after taking off in a severe thunderstorm on February 12, 1963.
* '''[[PBA Flight 1039]]''' crashed upon takeoff from [[Jacksonville International Airport]] on December 6, 1984, killing all 13 passengers and crew.
* '''[[Southern Airways Flight 49]]''' was successfully hijacked by three passengers and forced to fly to Cuba on November 10, 1972. Cuba returned the airplane, crew, passengers, and ransom money to the US and sentenced the hijackers to prison.
* '''[[ValuJet Flight 592]]''' crashed in the Florida [[Everglades]] on {{date|May 11, 1996}} when a fire started in a cargo hold during takeoff. All 110 on board were killed.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1997). [http://www.ntsb.gov/Publictn/1997/AAR9706.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: In-Flight Fire and Impact With Terrain Valujet Airlines Flight 592 DC-9-32, N904VJ Everglades, Near Miami, Florida May 11, 1996 (NTSB/AAR-97-06)]. Retrieved November 05, 2009.</ref>
==Georgia== * '''[[Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 529]]''' crashed near [[Carrollton, Georgia]] on August 21, 1995 due to [[mechanical failure]]. Nine of the 29 passengers and crew on board eventually died due to injuries suffered in the accident.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1996). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/1996/AAR9606.pdf In-flight Loss of Propeller Blade Forced Landing, and Collision with Terrain Atlantic Southeast Airlines, Inc., Flight 529 Embraer EMB-120RT, N256AS, Carrollton, Georgia, August 21, 1995]. Retrieved May 26, 2009</ref>
* '''[[Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 2311]]''' crashed near [[Brunswick, Georgia]], on April 5, 1991, killing all 23 passengers and crew, including former U.S. Senator [[John Tower]] and astronaut [[Sonny Carter]].<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1992). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR92-03.pdf Aircraft accident report: Atlantic Southeast Airlines, Inc., Flight 2311, uncontrolled collision with terrain, and Embraer EMB-120, N270AS Brunswick, Georgia April 5, 1991] (PDF). Retrieved November 05, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Eastern Air Lines Flight 21]]''' crashed while preparing to land at [[Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport|Candler Field]] on February 26, 1941. Eight of the 16 on board were killed. Among the injured was [[Eastern Air Lines]] president and [[World War I]] hero [[Eddie Rickenbacker]].<ref>{{cite conference | title = Report of the Civil Aeronautics Board | booktitle = Of the investigation of the accident involving civil aircraft of the United States No 28394 which occurred near Atlanta, Georgia, on February 26, 1941 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = June 12, 1941 | id = File No. 226-41 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=95%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
* '''[[Southern Airways Flight 242]]''' executed a [[forced landing]] on a [[highway]] in [[New Hope, Georgia|New Hope]], [[Paulding County, Georgia]] after suffering hail damage and losing thrust on both engines in a severe thunderstorm on April 4, 1977. 62 out of 85 passengers and crew on board were killed, as well as 9 more on the ground.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1978). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR78-03.pdf Aircraft accident report: Southern Airways, Inc., DC-9-31, N1335U, New Hope, Georgia, April 4, 1977]. Retrieved May 26, 2009</ref>
==Hawaii== [[File:561016PanAmDitches-2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Pan Am Flight 6]] is forced to make an emergency water landing in the Pacific Ocean on October 16, 1956.]] <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[Aloha Airlines Flight 243]]''' suffered explosive decompression when the passenger roof blew off during an inter-island flight on April 28, 1988. A flight attendant was killed, and the plane landed safely at [[Kahului Airport]].<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1989). [http://www.airdisaster.com/reports/ntsb/AAR89-03.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Aloha Airlines; Flight 243; Boeing 737-200, N73711; near Maui, Hawaii; April 28, 1988]. Retrieved December 5, 2010.</ref>
* '''[[Pan Am Flight 830]]''' made an emergency landing in [[Honolulu]] after a terrorist bomb exploded, killing a single passenger on August 11, 1982.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19820811-0|type=Criminal Occurrence}}</ref>
* '''[[Pan Am Flight 6]]''' is forced to make an emergency water landing in the [[Pacific Ocean]] northeast of [[Hawaii]] after two of its four engines failed on October 16, 1956. There were only a few minor injuries and no fatalities.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Report of the Civil Aeronautics Board | booktitle = | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = July 11, 1957 | id = File No. 1-0121 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=631%22 | accessdate = 2010-12-05 }}</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 811]]''' experienced a cargo door failure in flight on Friday, February 24, 1989, after its stopover at Honolulu International Airport, Hawaii. The resulting [[explosive decompression]] blew out several rows of seats, killing 9 passengers.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1992). [http://www.ntsb.org/Wiringcargodoorlite/Additional%20Aircraft%20Accident%20Reports_files/AAR92-3.pdf Aircraft Accident Report; Explosive Decompression -- Loss of Cargo Door in Flight; United Airlines Flight 811; Boeing 747-1 22, N4713U; Honolulu, Hawaii; February 24, 21989]. Retrieved December 5, 2010.</ref>
==Illinois== <!-- [[File:Southwest Airlines Flight 1248 -1.jpg|right|thumb|[[Southwest Airlines Flight 1248]] on December 8, 2005 after sliding off the runway and crashing into automobile traffic.]] Uncomment when this section gets big enough to support two images. --> * '''[[American Airlines Flight 191]]''' lost control and crashed immediately after take-off at [[O'Hare International Airport]], [[Chicago]] on May 25, 1979. Its No. 1 engine had been severed on the runway.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1979). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR79-17.pdf Aircraft accident report: American Airlines, Inc., DC-10-10, N110AA, Chicago-O'Hare International Airport, Chicago, Illinois, May 25, 1979]. Retrieved May 27, 2009</ref>
* '''[[American Airlines Flight 444]]''' was attacked by the [[Unabomber]] on November 15, 1979 near [[Chicago Illinois]]. The bomb planted in the cargo hold malfunctioned, but 12 passengers had to be treated for smoke inhalation.
* '''[[Northwest Orient Airlines Flight 706]]''' crashed during take-off from O'Hare International Airport on September 17, 1961, killing all 37 on board. The co-pilot's control of the [[aileron]] boost unit had been disconnected during maintenance.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Northwest Airlines, Inc.; Lockheed Electra, L-188C, N137US; O'Hare International Airport; Chicago, Illinois, September 17, 1961 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = December 10, 1962 | id = File No. 1-0018 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=728%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-27 }}</ref>
* '''[[Southwest Airlines Flight 1248]]''' slid off the runway while landing in a snowstorm at [[Chicago Midway Airport]] on December 8, 2005. The aircraft crashed into automobile traffic, killing a 6-year-old boy in a car.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (2007). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR07-06.pdf Aircraft accident report: runway overrun and collision Southwest Airlines flight 1248, Boeing 737-7H4, N471WN, Chicago Midway International Airport, Chicago, Ill, December 8, 2005]. Retrieved May 27, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 389]]''' crashed into [[Lake Michigan]] near [[Lake Forest, Illinois]] on August 16, 1965, killing all 30 on board. The [[National Transportation Safety Board|NTSB]] could not determine a definitive cause for the pilot's actions, though it is believed that it was most likely the result of the pilots misreading their three-pointer altimeters by {{convert|10000|ft}}.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = United Air Lines, Inc.; B-727, N7036U; In Lake Michigan August 16, 1965 | publisher = National Transportation Safety Board | date = December 19, 1967 | id = File No. 1-0030 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=785%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-27 }}</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 553]]''' struck trees and houses in [[Chicago]] before crashing into a house after an aborted landing at [[Chicago Midway International Airport]] on December 8, 1972. [[Illinois]] [[United States Congress|Congress]]man [[George W. Collins]] and the wife of [[Watergate]] conspirator [[E. Howard Hunt]], [[Dorothy Hunt]], were killed in the crash.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1973). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR73-16.pdf Aircraft accident report: United Air Lines, Inc., Boeing 737, N9031U, Chicago Midway Airport, Chicago, Illinois, December 8, 1972]. Retrieved May 27, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[United Express Flight 4925]]''' collided with a Beechcraft [[King Air]] while landing in [[Quincy, Illinois]] on November 16, 1996. All 14 people aboard both aircraft were killed.
==Indiana== * '''[[Allegheny Airlines Flight 853]]''' crashed southeast of [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]] on {{date|September 9, 1969}} due to collision with a private plane, killing all 83 people aboard both aircraft.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1970). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR70-15.pdf Aircraft accident report: Allegheny Airlines, Inc., DC-9, N988VJ, and a Forth Corporation Piper PA-28, N7374J, near Fairland, Indiana, September 9, 1969] (PDF). Accessed: November 05, 2009</ref>
* '''[[American Eagle Flight 4184]]''' crashed near [[Roselawn, Indiana]] due to icing on {{date|October 31, 1994}}, killing all 68 on board.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1996). [http://www.ntsb.gov/Publictn/1996/aar9602.pdf In-flight Icing Encounter and Loss of Control Simmons Airlines, d.b.a. American Eagle Flight 4184 Avions de Transport Regional (ATR) Model 72-212, N401AM, Roselawn, Indiana October 31, 1994] (PDF). Accessed: November 05, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Northwest Orient Airlines Flight 710]]''' crashed near [[Cannelton, Indiana]] on March 17, 1960, killing all 57 passengers and 6 crewmembers.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Northwest Airlines Lockheed Electra, N 121US, Near Cannelton, Indiana, March 17, 1960 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = April 24, 1961 | id = Docket No. SA-354, File No. 1-0003 | url = http://ntl1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?file&fn=8&name=*S%3A%5CDOT_56GB%5Cairplane%20accidents%5Cwebsearch%5C031760.pdf | accessdate = 2009-11-05 }}</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Chesterton Crash|United Airlines tail number NC13304]]''' was destroyed by a bomb on {{date|October 10, 1933}} near [[Chesterton, Indiana]], in what is thought to be the first proven act of air sabotage in the history of commercial aviation.<ref>{{cite news |title= WRECK OF AIR LINER LAID TO A BOMB; United Company Asserts Evidence Found by Expert Sustains Theory. PLANE WAS BLOWN APART The Justice Department Sends Agents to Newark and Cleveland to Investigate Servicing.|author= |newspaper= The New York Times|date= 14 October 1933|url= http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70610F63D5516738DDDAD0994D8415B838FF1D3&scp=1&sq=Wreck%20of%20air%20liner%20laid%20to%20a%20bomb&st=cse | page=5 | accessdate= 2009-11-05}}</ref>
==Iowa== * A [[Beechcraft Bonanza]] crashed near [[Clear Lake, Iowa]] on February 3, 1959, '''[[The Day the Music Died|killing three American rock 'n' roll musicians]]''': [[Buddy Holly]], [[Ritchie Valens]], and [[The Big Bopper|J. P. "The Big Bopper" Richardson]]. * '''[[United Airlines Flight 232]]''' - Crash-landed at [[Sioux Gateway Airport]] in [[Sioux City]] after explosion of the No. 2 engine destroyed all three hydraulic systems
==Kansas==
* '''[[TWA Flight 599]]''' crashed near [[Cottonwood Falls, Kansas]] on March 31, 1931, killing all eight aboard, including [[University of Notre Dame]] football coach [[Knute Rockne]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.planecrashinfo.com/1931/1931-7.htm|title=PlaneCrashInfo.com: TWA Flight 599 Accident Details|accessdate=2009-05-25}}</ref>
==Kentucky== * '''[[Air Canada Flight 797]]''' - Emergency landed at [[Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport]]; fire consumed much of the aircraft
* '''[[Air Tahoma Flight 185]]''' ran out of fuel and crashed as it approached the runway at [[Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport]] on August 13, 2004. One person, the first officer, was killed.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (2006). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/2006/AAR0603.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Crash During Approach to Landing, Air Tahoma, Inc., Flight 185, Convair 580, N586P, Covington, Kentucky, August 13, 2004]. Retrieved May 26, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[American Airlines Flight 63 (Flagship Ohio)|American Airlines Flight 63]]''' lost control due to severe turbulence and violent downdrafts and crashed near Trammel, Kentucky, killing 20 out of 22 people on board.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = REPORT OF THE CIVIL AERONAUTICS BOARD on the Investigation of an Accident Involving Aircraft In Scheduled Air Carrier Operation | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = April 22, 1944 | id = File No. 3525-43 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=177%22 | accessdate = 2007-01-25 }}</ref>
* '''[[American Airlines Flight 383]]''' crashed on approach to [[Northern Kentucky International Airport|Greater Cincinnati Airport]] on November 8, 1965, and only 3 passengers and 1 flight attendant survived.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aviation Investigation Report | booktitle = American Airlines, Inc.; Boeing 727, N1996; Near the Greater Cincinnati Airport; Constance, Kentucky; November 8, 1965 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = September 28, 1966 | id = File No. 1-0031 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=787%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
* '''[[Comair Flight 191]]''' crashed while attempting to take off from [[Blue Grass Airport]] on August 27, 2006, killing all 47 passengers and 2 out of 3 crewmembers.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (2009). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/2007/AAR0705.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Attempted Takeoff From Wrong Runway Comair Flight 5191 Bombardier CL-600-2B19, N431CA Lexington, Kentucky August 27, 2006]. Retrieved May 26, 2009</ref>
* '''[[Comair Flight 444]]''' crashed shortly after takeoff from [[Cincinnati-Northern Kentucky International Airport]] on October 8, 1979, killing all on board.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1980). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR80-08.pdf Aircraft accident report: COMAIR, Inc., Piper PA-31, N6642L, Covington, Kentucky, October 8, 1979]. Retrieved May 26, 2009</ref>
* The '''[[1955 Cincinnati mid-air collision]]''' between a [[TWA]] [[Martin 2-0-2]] and a [[Douglas DC-2]] on January 12, 1955, killing all on board both aircraft.
* '''[[TWA Flight 128]]''' struck trees on [[final approach (aviation)|final approach]] and crashed {{convert|9357|ft|m}} short of the runway at [[Northern Kentucky International Airport|Greater Cincinnati Airport]] on November 20, 1967.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1969). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR69-05.pdf Aircraft accident report: Trans World Airlines, Inc., Convair 880, N821TW, Constance, Kentucky, November 20, 1967]. Retrieved May 26, 2009</ref>
* '''[[TWA Flight 159]]''' rolled off the runway after the captain aborted a takeoff at [[Greater Cincinnati Airport]] on November 6, 1967. The aircraft crashed and caught fire. One passenger died later of injuries sustained during the crash.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1968). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR68-AK.pdf Aircraft accident report: Trans World Airlines, Inc. B-707, N742Tw, The Greater Cincinnati Airport, Erlanger, Kentucky, November 6, 1967]. Retrieved May 26, 2009</ref>
==Louisiana== * '''[[Eastern Air Lines Flight 304]]''' crashed into [[Lake Pontchartrain]] on February 25, 1964, killing all 58 on board.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Eastern Air Lines, Inc; Douglas DC-8, N8607; New Orleans, Louisiana; February 25, 1964 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = July 1, 1966 | id = Docket No. SA-379, File No. 1-0006 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=769%22 | accessdate = 2010-12-05 }}</ref>
* '''[[National Airlines Flight 967]]''' disappeared over the [[Gulf of Mexico]] near [[New Orleans]] on November 16, 1959 with 42 passengers and crew on board. Several bodies and some scattered debris were recovered, though the main section of wreckage was never found. The cause was presumed to be a bombing, though investigators were unable to prove it.
* '''[[Pan Am Flight 759]]''' - Crashed in [[Kenner, Louisiana]] shortly after takeoff from [[Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport|New Orleans]].
* '''[[TACA Flight 110]]''' made a successful [[deadstick landing]] on a grass [[levee]] at [[NASA]]'s [[Michoud Assembly Facility]] in eastern [[New Orleans]] after losing thrust in both engines on May 24, 1988. There were no casualties or serious injuries.
==Maine== <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[Bar Harbor Airlines Flight 1808]]''' crashed short of the runway at [[Bangor International Airport]] on August 25, 1985, killing all on board, including 13-year-old [[Samantha Smith]], the "Goodwill Ambassador" to the [[Soviet Union]].<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1986). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR86-06.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Bar Harbor Airlines Flight 1808; Beech BE-99, N300WP; Auburn-Lewiston Municipal Airport, Auburn, Maine; August 25, 1985]. Retrieved May 25, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[TWA Flight 277]]''' crashed into [[Fort Mountain (Main)|Fort Mountain]] in [[Baxter State Park]] on June 20, 1944. Heavy wind and rain had blown the [[C-54 Skymaster]] off-course, and the pilot suffered a bout of [[spatial disorientation]] and did not realize his position in relation to the mountain. The pilot and all six passengers were killed.
==Maryland== * '''[[Capital Airlines Flight 75]]''' crashed in [[Chase, Maryland]] on {{date|May 12, 1959}} due to a weather-induced loss of control. All perished.<ref>[[Civil Aeronautics Board]]. Docket #SA-341. File #1-0050. October 23, 1959. [http://ntl1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=682%22 html]. [[US Department of Transportation]]. Accessed online on September 8, 2009.</ref>
* The rudder on board '''[[MetroJet Flight 2710]]''' malfunctioned, causing the jet to roll violently on February 23, 1999. The crew was able to regain control and landed safely at [[Baltimore-Washington International Airport]].
* '''[[Pan Am Flight 214]]''' crashed near [[Elkton, Maryland]], on {{date|December 8, 1963}} after being struck by [[lightning]].<ref name="cab">[[Civil Aeronautics Board]]. File #1-0015. December 08, 1963. [http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?file&fn=8&name=*P%3A%5CDOT%5Cairplane%20accidents%5Cwebsearch%5C120863.pdf pdf]. [[US Department of Transportation]]. Accessed online on September 8, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 297]]''' crashed near [[Columbia, Maryland]] on {{date|November 23, 1962}} after a [[bird strike]].<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19621123-1|type=Accident|accessdate=2009-09-08}}</ref>
==Massachusetts== * '''[[Air New England Flight 248]]''' crashed on approach to [[Barnstable Municipal Airport]] on June 17, 1979. The cause was determined to be pilot fatigue. One crew member was killed.
* '''[[Aer Lingus Flight 132]]''', an [[Airbus A330]] "St. Maeve" and [[US Airways Flight 1170]], a [[Boeing 737]] almost collide while both were taking off on intersecting runways at [[Logan International Airport]], [[Boston]].
* '''[[Colgan Air Flight 9446]]''' crashed into the water off of [[Yarmouth, Massachusetts]] shortly after takeoff on August 26, 2003. Improper maintenance and pilot error led to a loss of control in-flight. The pilot and co-pilot, the only people on board, perished.
* '''[[Delta Air Lines Flight 723]]''' crashed while landing at [[Logan International Airport]] on July 31, 1973, killing all 89 on board.
* '''[[Eastern Air Lines Flight 375]]''' crashed on takeoff from [[Logan International Airport]] on October 4, 1960. 10 survived.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Eastern Air Lines, Inc., Lockheed Electra L-188 N 5533, Logan International Airport, Boston, Massachusetts, October 4, 1960 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = July 31, 1962 | id = Docket No. SA-3, File No. 1-0043 | url = http://dotlib58rary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=715%22 | accessdate = 2010-12-05 }}</ref>
* '''[[EgyptAir Flight 990]]''' plummeted into the [[Atlantic Ocean]], about {{convert|60|mi|km}} south of [[Nantucket|Nantucket Island]], killing all 217 people on board.
* '''[[World Airways Flight 30]]''' overshot the runway due to [[ice|icy conditions]] on January 23, 1982, killing 2 passengers.
==Michigan== <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[Capital Airlines Flight 67]]''' crashed on final approach to [[Freeland Tri-City Airport]] during a severe snowstorm on April 6, 1958.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Capital Airlines, Inc.; Viscount, Tri-City Airport; Freeland, Michigan; April 6, 1958 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = February 11, 1965 | id = File No. 1-00 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=662%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
* '''[[Comair Flight 3272]]''' - Crashed on approach to [[Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport]], near [[Detroit]].<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1998). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR98-04.pdf Aircraft accident report: in-flight icing encounter and uncontrolled collision with terrain, COMAIR flight 3272, Embraer EMB-120RT, N265CA, Monroe, Michigan, January 9, 1997]. Retrieved May 28, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Northwest Airlines Flight 253]]''' was the target of the attempted [[al-Qaida]] "Christmas Day bombing" on December 25, 2009. [[Nigeria]]n-born [[Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab]] attempted to detonate plastic explosives concealed in his underwear, but was stopped by other passengers.
* '''[[Northwest Airlines Flight 255]]''' - Crashed after takeoff from [[Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport]], near [[Detroit]]
* '''[[Northwest Airlines Flight 299]]''' collided with '''[[Northwest Airlines Flight 1482]]''' on an active runway at [[Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport]] in heavy fog on December 3, 1990.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1991). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR91-05.pdf Aircraft accident report: Northwest Airlines, Inc., Flights 1482 and 299, runway incursion and collision, Detroit Metropolitan/Wayne County Airport, Romulus, Michigan, December 3, 1990]. Retrieved May 28, 2009.</ref> Seven passengers and one crewperson from Flight 1482 were killed.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19901203-1|title=Northwest Airlines Flight 1482|accessdate=2009-05-28}}</ref> There were no injuries on board Flight 299.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19901203-2|title=Northwest Airlines Flight 299|accessdate=2009-05-28}}</ref>
* '''[[Northwest Orient Airlines Flight 2501]]''' disappeared on the night of June 23, 1950 over [[Benton Harbor]] on [[Lake Michigan]]. The plane was never found.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = Northwest Airlines, Inc. – Benton Harbor, Mich., June 23, 1950 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = January 18, 1951 | id = File No. F-111-56 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=463%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
* A '''[[1956 Trans-Canada Air Lines accident|Trans-Canada Viscount Vickers]]''' diverted to [[Windsor, Ontario]] after the blade of the propeller broke off and sliced through the passenger section of the cabin, killing one passenger and injuring four passengers and one flight attendant on July 9, 1956 while flying over [[Flat Rock, Michigan]].<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = Trans-Canada Air Lines Viscount, CF-TGR, Flat Rock, Michigan, July 9, 1956 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = March 1, 1957 | id = File No. F-111-56 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=625%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-26 }}</ref>
* '''[[TWA Flight 841 (1979)|TWA Flight 841]]''' made an emergency landing at [[Detroit, Michigan]] after losing control and barrel-rolling at supersonic speeds on April 4, 1979. No fatalities occurred among the 82 passengers and seven crew members, though eight passengers reported minor injuries relating to high G forces. The exact cause of the accident is disputed.
== Minnesota == * '''[[Northwest Airlines Flight 188]]''' lost contact with air traffic controllers and significantly overshot its destination when the pilots became distracted on October 21, 2009.
==Missouri== * '''[[Continental Airlines Flight 11]]''', a Boeing 707, near Unionville, Missouri due to bomb exploded by a passenger on May 22, 1962.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Continental Air Lines, Inc., Boeing 707-124, N 70775, Near Unionville, Missouri, May 22, 1962 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = August 1, 1962 | id = File No. 1-0003 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=741%22 | accessdate = 2010-12-05 }}</ref>
* '''[[Continental Airlines Flight 12]]''' overran the runway at [[Kansas City Downtown Airport]] on July 1, 1965.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Continental Air Lines, Inc., B-707-124, N70773, Kansas City Municipal Airport, Kansas City, Missouri | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = June 24, 1966 | id = File No. 1-0019 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=783%22 | accessdate = 2010-12-05 }}</ref>
* '''[[Corporate Airlines Flight 5966]]''' crashed on approach to [[Kirksville Airport]] on October 19, 2004, killing thirteen.
* '''[[Pinnacle Airlines Flight 3701]]''' crashed on October 14, 2004, near [[Jefferson City, Missouri]] after [[engine flameout]] and subsequent [[pilot error]].
* '''[[TWA Flight 427]]''' struck a [[Cessna 441]] while on a takeoff roll at [[Lambert-St. Louis International Airport]] on November 22, 1994. The two people on board the Cessna were killed instantly.
== Montana== * '''[[Northwest Airlines Flight 1]]''' crashed {{convert|0.5|mi|km}} southwest of the [[Miles City, Montana]] airport on January 13, 1939 after a fire broke out in the [[cockpit]].<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = Air Safety Board Report; To the Civil Aeronautics Authority as a Result of an Investigation of an Accident Involving Aircraft | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = | id = | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=78%22 | accessdate = 2010-12-05 }}</ref>
* '''[[Northwest Airlines Flight 2]]''' crashed into the [[Bridger Mountains (Montana)|Bridger Mountains]] about {{convert|12|mi|km}} northeast of [[Bozeman, Montana]], on January 10, 1938. This was the first fatal crash for Northwest Airlines.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = Report of the Investigating Board | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = January 29, 1939 | id = | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=66%22 | accessdate = 2010-12-05 }}</ref>
==Nebraska== <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[Braniff Flight 250]]''' broke up midair and crashed near [[Falls City, Nebraska]] on August 6, 1966 after flying into an active squall line. All 42 on board killed.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1968). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR68-AL.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Braniff Airways, Inc.; BAC 1-11, N1553; Near Falls City, Nebraska; August 6, 1966]. Retrieved May 25, 2009</ref>
==Nevada== * '''[[Bonanza Air Lines Flight 114]]''' crashed into a mountain about {{convert|8|mi|km}} south of [[McCarran International Airport]] on November 15, 1964. The airplane immediately exploded, killing all 29 on board. This was the first and only fatal crash for the airline.
* '''[[Galaxy Airlines Flight 203]]''' crashed by [[Reno/Tahoe International Airport|Reno-Cannon International Airport]] about {{convert|1.5|mi|km}} from the end of the runway and burst into flames on January 21, 1985. The only survivor was a 17-year-old passenger who was thrown clear of the plane.
* '''[[TWA Flight 3]]''' crashed into [[Mount Potosi]] 23 minutes after takeoff from [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] on January 16, 1942. All 22 on board are killed, including movie star [[Carole Lombard]].<ref>{{cite conference | title = Report of the Civil Aeronautics Board | booktitle = | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = July 20, 1942 | id = Docket No. SA-58, File No. 119-42 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=120%22 | accessdate = 2010-12-05 }}</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 736]]''', collided with a [[US Air Force]] [[F-100 Super Sabre]] fighter on a training mission near [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] on April 21, 1958. All 47 aboard the airliner and both F-100 crew members are killed.
==New Hampshire== *'''[[Northeast Airlines Flight 946]]''' crashed near [[Etna, New Hampshire]] on October 25, 1968, killing 32 passengers and crew. The [[National Transportation Safety Board|NTSB]] determined that the plane was flying {{convert|600|ft}} below its required altitude, though the reason for this is unknown. The NTSB report suggests that the pilots misjudged their altitude position during approach due to a lack of [[navigational aid]]s on the aircraft and near the airport.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board. (1970). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR70-07.pdf Aircraft accident report: Northeast Airlines, Inc., Fairchild Hiller FH-227C, N380NE, near Hanover, New Hampshire, October 25, 1968]. Retrieved May 27, 2009.</ref>
== New Jersey == [[File:FedEx_Express_Flight_14_wreckage_(1997).jpg|right|thumb|[[FedEx Flight 14]] at [[Newark International Airport]] after crashing and catching fire.]] * '''[[American Airlines Flight 6780]]''' crashed into a house in [[Elizabeth, New Jersey]], {{convert|3.4|mi|km}} southeast of the airport on January 22, 1952. The cause of the crash was never determined. This was the first fatal crash of a [[Convair 240]].<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = American Airlines, Inc., --Elizabeth, New Jersey, January 22, 1952 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = April 25, 1952 | id = File No. 1-0016 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=506%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-28 }}</ref>
* '''[[Continental Airlines Flight 1883]]''' accidentally landed on a [[taxiway]] instead of a [[runway]] at [[Newark Liberty International Airport]], on October 28, 2006.
* '''[[FedEx Flight 14]]''' crashed during landing at [[Newark International Airport]] on July 31, 1997. The pilot was unable to slow down the descent of the aircraft, and it bounced and rolled on the runway, eventually coming to rest on its back and catching fire.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board. (2000). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/2000/AAR0002.pdf Aircraft accident report: crash during landing, Federal Express, Inc. McDonnell Douglas MD-11, N611FE, Newark International Airport, Newark, New Jersey, July 31, 1997]. Retrieved May 28, 2009.</ref>
== New Mexico == <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[TWA Flight 260]]''' deviated from its prescribed flight path and crashed into the [[Sandia Mountains]] on February 19, 1955 for reasons unknown.<ref>{{ASN accident|title=TWA Flight 260|accessdate=2009-05-25|id=19550219-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite conference | title = Aorcraft Accident Report 1 | booktitle = Trans World Airlines, Inc., Sandia Mountain, Near Albuquerque, New Mexico, February 19, 1955 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = June 9, 1960 | id = File No. 1-0063 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=590%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-28 }}</ref>
==New York== <!-- Please try to keep this list in alphabetic and then numeric order. Ex: American Airlines Flight 1, American Airlines Flight 50, American Airlines Flight 320, etc. Alphabetic by airline, numeric within the airline. --> [[File:Plane crash into Hudson River (crop).jpg|thumb|right|[[US Airways Flight 1549]] crashed into the Hudson River on January 15, 2009]]
* '''[[American Airlines Flight 1]]''' crashed immediately after takeoff from [[Idlewild Airport]] (now JFK airport), New York City on {{date|March 1, 1962}}.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = American Airlines, Inc., Boeing 707-123B, N 7506A, Jamaica Bay, Long Island, New York, March 1, 1962 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = January 16, 1963 | id = Docket No. SA-366, File No. 1-0001 | url = http://specialcollection.dotlibrary.dot.gov/ | accessdate = 2009-11-12 }}</ref>
* '''[[American Airlines Flight 11]]''' was hijacked after takeoff from Boston during the [[September 11, 2001 attacks|September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks]]. The aircraft was subsequently crashed into the North Tower of the [[World Trade Center]] in Manhattan, New York City.
* '''[[American Airlines Flight 320]]''' crashed in the [[East River]] on approach to [[LaGuardia Airport]], New York City on {{date|February 3, 1959}}. 65 of the 73 people on board perished.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = American Airlines, Inc., Lockheed Electra, N 6101A, In the East River, La Guardia Airport, New York, February 3, 1959 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = January 10, 1960 | id = Docket No. SA-339, File No. 1-0038 | url = http://specialcollection.dotlibrary.dot.gov/ | accessdate = 2009-11-12 }}</ref>
* '''[[American Airlines Flight 587]]''' crashed in [[Belle Harbor]], [[Queens]], New York City after takeoff from [[John F. Kennedy International Airport]] on {{date|November 12, 2001}}.
* '''[[American Airlines Flight 723]]''' crashed in [[Colonie, New York]] while attempting to land at [[Albany International Airport|Albany Airport]]. All 28 people on board perished.
* '''[[Avianca Flight 52]]''' crashed at [[Cove Neck]], [[Long Island]], after running out of fuel on {{date|January 25, 1990}}.
* '''[[Colgan Air Flight 3407]]''' crashed six miles from the runway at [[Buffalo Niagara International Airport]] on February 12, 2009.
* '''[[Eastern Air Lines Flight 66]]''' crashed after striking the runway lights at [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|Kennedy airport]] on {{date|June 24, 1975}}.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1976). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR76-08.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Eastern Air Lines, Inc.; Boeing 727-225, N8845E; John F. Kennedy International Airport; Jamaica, New York; June 24, 1975]. Retrieved December 5, 2010.</ref>
* '''[[Eastern Air Lines Flight 512]]''' crashed during go-round after failing to land at [[Idlewild Airport]] in the fog on {{date|November 30, 1962}}. 25 people (4 crew, 21 passengers) perished.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Eastern Air Lines, Inc., DC-7B, N 815D, New York International Airport, Jamaica, New York, November 30, 1962 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = October 10, 1963 | id = Docket No. SA-368, File No. 1.0033 | url = http://specialcollection.dotlibrary.dot.gov/ | accessdate = 2009-11-12 }}</ref>
* '''[[Eastern Air Lines Flight 663]]''' crashed at [[Jones Beach State Park]] after takeoff from [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|Kennedy airport]] when forced to evade inbound PanAm Flight 212 on {{date|February 8, 1965}}.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Eastern Air Lines, Inc., DC-73, N849D; In the Atlantic Ocean 6.5 Nautical Miles; South-Southwest of Jones Beach; Long Island, New York; February 8, 1965 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = November 17, 1966 | id = Docket No. SA-381, File No. 1-0001 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=779%22 | accessdate = 2010-12-05 }}</ref>
* '''[[Mohawk Airlines Flight 121]]''' crashed during takeoff from Rochester-Monroe airport on July 2, 1963, killing 7 people and injuring 36.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Mohawk Airlines, Inc., Martin 404, N449A, Rochester-Monroe County Airport, Rochester, New York, July 2, 1963 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = October 10, 1963 | id = Docket No. SA-374, File No. 1-0008 | url = http://specialcollection.dotlibrary.dot.gov/ | accessdate = 2009-11-13 }} [http://ntl1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?file&fn=8&name=*S%3A%5CDOT_56GB%5Cairplane%20accidents%5Cwebsearch%5C070263.pdf PDF]</ref>
* '''[[Mohawk Airlines Flight 405]]''' crashed into a house on March 3, 1972, on final approach to [[Albany International Airport]], killing 17 people.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1973). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR73-08.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Mohawk Airlines, Inc.; Fairchild Hiller FH-227B, N7818M; Albany, New York; March 3, 1972]. (PDF.) Retrieved December 5, 2010.</ref>
* '''[[Mohawk Airlines Flight 411]]''' crashed into [[Pilot Knob (Iron County, Missouri)|Pilot Knob]] on November 19, 1969, killing all 14 passengers and crew on board.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1970). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-report/AAR70-12.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Mohawk Airlines, Inc.; Fiarchild Hiller FH-227B, N7811M; Near Glens Falls, New York; November 19, 1969]. (PDF.) Retrieved December 5, 2010.</ref>
* '''[[Northeast Airlines Flight 823]]''' crashed on [[Rikers Island]], New York City, during takeoff from [[LaGuardia Airport]] on {{date|February 1, 1957}}.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Northeast Airlines, Inc., DC-6A, N 34954, Rikers Island, New York, February 1, 1957 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = March 10, 1958 | id = Docket No. SA-324, File No. 1-0061 | url = http://specialcollection.dotlibrary.dot.gov/ | accessdate = 2009-11-13 }}</ref>
* '''[[Northwest Airlines Flight 6231]]''' crashed near [[Stony Point, New York]] on December 1, 1974 due to pilot error. All 3 crew on board were killed.
* The '''[[1965 Carmel mid-air collision]]''' between TWA Flight 42 and Eastern Air Lines Flight 853 over [[Carmel, New York]] on December 4, 1965.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Midair Collision - Trans World Airlines, Inc., Boeing 707-131B, N748TW, and Eastern Air Lines, Inc., Lockheed 1049C, near Carmel, New York, December 4, 1965 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = December 20, 1966 | id = Docket No. SA-389, File No. 1-0033 | url = http://specialcollection.dotlibrary.dot.gov/ | accessdate = 2009-11-13 }} [http://ntl1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?file&fn=8&name=*S:\DOT_56GB\airplane%20accidents\websearch\120465.pdf PDF]</ref>
* '''[[1960 New York air disaster|TWA Flight 266]]''' (inbound to [[Idlewild Airport]]) and United Airlines Flight 826 (inbound to [[LaGuardia Airport]]) collided over Miller Field, [[Staten Island]], New York City on {{date|December 16, 1960}}. The TWA aircraft crashed at the site while the United aircraft continued flying for 8 miles until it crashed in the [[Park Slope]] section of [[Brooklyn]].<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = United Air Lines, Inc., DC-8, N 8013U, and Trans World Airlines, Inc., Constellation 1049A, N 6907C, near Staten Island, New York, December 16, 1960 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = June 18, 1962 | id = Docket No. SA-361, File No. 1-0083 | url = http://specialcollection.dotlibrary.dot.gov/ | accessdate = 2009-11-13 }} [http://ntl1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?file&fn=8&name=*S:\DOT_56GB\airplane%20accidents\websearch\121660.pdf PDF]</ref>
* '''[[TWA Flight 800]]''' exploded in mid-air and crashed into the [[Atlantic Ocean]] near [[East Moriches, New York]] on July 17, 1996, killing all 230 people on board.
* '''[[TWA Flight 843]]''' crashed and burst into flames after an aborted takeoff from [[John F. Kennedy International Airport]] on July 30, 1992. All 292 people on board were safely evacuated.
[[File:UA Flight 175 hits WTC south tower 9-11 edit.jpeg|thumb|right|[[United Flight 175]] moments after impacting the South Tower of the WTC, Sept 11, 2001.]]
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 175]]''' was hijacked after takeoff from Boston during the [[September 11, 2001 attacks|September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks]]. The aircraft was subsequently crashed into the South Tower of the World Trade Center in Manhattan, New York City.
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 521]]''' failed to get airborne during takeoff on {{date|May 29, 1947}}. The aircraft overran the end of the runway, ripped through an airport fence, barreled through traffic on the [[Grand Central Parkway]], and then slammed into an embankment before ultimately plunging into a pond and exploding.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = United Air Lines, Inc., LaGuardia Field, New York, May 29, 1947 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = | id = Docket No. SA-144 | url = http://specialcollection.dotlibrary.dot.gov/ | accessdate = 2009-11-13 }}</ref>
* '''[[US Airways Flight 1549]]''' was a commercial flight from LaGuardia Airport (LGA) in New York City to Charlotte/Douglas International Airport (CLT) in Charlotte, North Carolina that on January 15, 2009, made an emergency water landing in the Hudson River about six minutes after takeoff.
* '''[[USAir Flight 405]]''' crashed during takeoff from [[LaGuardia Airport]] on {{date|March 22, 1992}}.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1993). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR93-02.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Takeoff Stall in Icing Conditions; USAir Flight 405; Fokker F-28, N485US; LaGuardia Airport, Flushing, New York; March 22, 1992]. (PDF.) Retrieved December 5, 2010.</ref>
* '''[[USAir Flight 5050]]''' crashed during an aborted takeoff from [[LaGuardia Airport]] on {{date|September 20, 1989}}.
==North Carolina== * '''[[Air Midwest Flight 5481]]''' crashed into an airport hangar and burst into flames 37 seconds after leaving [[Charlotte/Douglas International Airport]], killing all 21 on board on January 8, 2003.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/2004/AAR0401.pdf|format=PDF|title=Aircraft Accident Report: Loss of Pitch Control During Takeoff; Air Midwest Flight 5481; Raytheon (Beechcraft) 1900D, N233YV; Charlotte, North Carolina; January 8, 2003|date=2004-02-26|publisher=[[National Transportation Safety Board]]|accessdate=2010-12-05}}</ref>
* '''[[Eastern Air Lines Flight 212]]''' crashed while attempting to land in thick fog at [[Charlotte/Douglas International Airport|Douglas Municipal Airport]] on September 11, 1974, killing 71 on board.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.airdisaster.com/reports/ntsb/AAR75-09.pdf|format=PDF|title=Aircraft Accident Report: Eastern Air Lines, Inc.; Douglas DC-9-31, N8984E; Charlotte, North Carolina; September 11, 1974|date=1975-05-23|publisher=[[National Transportation Safety Board]]|accessdate=2010-12-05}}</ref>
* '''[[National Airlines Flight 2511]]''' exploded over [[Bolivia, North Carolina]] on {{date|January 6, 1960}} when a passenger detonated dynamite in a suicide attempt.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = National Airlines Inc, Douglas DC-6B, N 8225H, Near Bolivia, North Carolina, January 6, 1960 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = July 29, 1960 | id = Docket No. SA-352, File No. 1-0002 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=705%22 | accessdate = 2010-12-05 }}</ref>
* '''[[Piedmont Airlines Flight 22]]''' collided with a [[Cessna 310]] over [[Hendersonville, North Carolina]] on July 19, 1967, killing all on board both aircraft.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.airdisaster.com/reports/ntsb/AAR68-AJ.pdf|format=PDF|title=Aircraft Accident Report: Piedmont Aviation, Inc.; Piedmont Airlines Division; Boeing 727, N68650; Lanseair Inc., Cessna 310, N31215; Midair Collision; Hendersonville, North Carolina; July 19, 1967 |date=1968-09-05|publisher=[[National Transportation Safety Board]]|accessdate=2010-12-05}}</ref>
* '''[[Piedmont Airlines Flight 467]]''' overran the runway after touchdown at [[Charlotte/Douglas International Airport]] on October 25, 1986. There were no fatalities.
* '''[[US Airways Flight 1016]]''' crashed while attempting to land during a severe thunderstorm at [[Charlotte/Douglas International Airport]] on July 2, 1994. Strong [[wind shear]] and a [[microburst]] caused the pilots to lose control of the aircraft; 37 people were killed and 20 survived.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR95-03.pdf|format=PDF|title=Aircraft Accident Report: Flight into Terrain During Missed Approach; USAir Flight 1016, DC-9-31, N954VJ; Charlotte/Douglas International Airport; Charlotte, North Carolina; July 2, 1994|date=|publisher=[[National Transportation Safety Board]]|accessdate=2010-12-05}}</ref>
==Ohio== * '''[[Atlantic Coast Airlines Flight 6291]]''' crashed on approach to [[Port Columbus International Airport]], [[Ohio]] on January 7, 1994, killing five of nine people on board. The cause of the crash was attributed to pilot error.
* '''[[Cal Poly football team plane crash]]''' - October 29, 1960<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Arctic-Pacific, Inc., Curtiss Wright, Super C-46F, N 1244N, Toledo Express Airport, Toledo, Ohio October 29, 1960 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = January 22, 1962 | id = Docket No. SA-360, File No. 1-0047 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=717%22 | accessdate = 2010-12-05 }}</ref>
* '''[[TWA Flight 553]]''' collided in midair with a [[Beechcraft Baron]] on March 9, 1967 over [[Urbana, Ohio]]. All people on both aircraft were killed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.airdisaster.com/reports/ntsb/AAR68-AI.pdf|format=PDF|title=Aircraft Accident Report. Trans World Airlines, Inc., Douglas DC-9, Tann Company Beechcraft Baron B-55 Inflight Collision Near Urbana, Ohio, March 9, 1967|date=|publisher=[[National Transportation Safety Board]]|accessdate=2010-12-05}}</ref>
==Oregon== * '''[[United Airlines Flight 173]]''' ran out of fuel and crashed while attempting to land near [[Portland, Oregon]] on {{date|December 28, 1978}}. 10 of 189 people on board perished.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1979).
