[http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR79-07.pdf "United Airlines, Inc.; McDonnel-Douglas, DC-8-61, N8082U; Portland, Oregon; December 28, 1978".]. Retrieved October 22, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[West Coast Airlines Flight 956]]''' crashed with eighteen fatal injuries and no survivors {{convert|5.5|mi|km}} south of [[Wemme, Oregon]] on {{date|October 1, 1966}}. This was the first commercial loss of a [[Douglas DC-9]].<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1967). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR67-AF.pdf "Aircraft Accident Report: West Coast Airlines, Inc.; DC-9, N9101; Near Wemme, Oregon".]. Retrieved October 22, 2009.</ref>
==Pennsylvania== * '''[[Mohawk Airlines Flight 40]]''' lost control and crashed over [[Blossburg, Pennsylvania]] on June 23, 1967, killing all 34 people on board. It was the deadliest disaster in the airline's history.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1968). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR68-AG.pdf "Aircraft Accident Report: Mohawk Airlines, Inc.; BAC 1-11, N1116J; Near Blossburg, Pennsylvania; June 23, 1967".]. Retrieved October 22, 2009.</ref>
*'''[[TWA Flight 1]]''', a [[Douglas DC-2]], crashed into [[Cheat Mountain (Pennsylvania)|Cheat Mountain]], near [[Uniontown, Pennsylvania]], approximately 10:20 a.m. [[Eastern Standard Time]] April 7, 1936, killing 12 of the 14 passengers and crew aboard.<ref>Special to the New York Times. [http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00910FD345F167B93CAA9178FD85F428385F9&scp=1 "11 killed, 3 hurt in airliner crash on mountain top"], ''The New York Times''. April 8, 1936. Page 1.</ref>
* '''[[TWA Flight 400]]''' crashed during takeoff from [[Greater Pittsburgh International Airport]] on April 1, 1956. Twenty-two of 36 people aboard were killed.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = Trans World Airlines, Inc., Martin 404, N 40403, Near Greater Pittsburgh Airport, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, April 1, 1956 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = September 11, 1956 | id = File No. 1-0070 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=618%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-27 }}</ref>
* '''[[TWA Flight 513]]''' crashed near [[Reading, Pennsylvania|Reading]] on July 11, 1946 while on a training flight. TWA subsequently grounded its [[Lockheed Super Constellation|Constellation]] fleet for 30 days.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., Reading, PA., July 11, 1946 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = November 29, 1946 | id = File No. 1232-46 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=340%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-27 }}</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 93]]''' was hijacked after takeoff from [[Newark, New Jersey]] on September 11, 2001. Passengers fought the hijackers after learning of the incidents at the [[World Trade Center]] and the hijackers' plans to use the aircraft for terrorism; their battle ended when the plane to crashed into a field in [[Somerset County, Pennsylvania|Somerset County]] (''See also: [[September 11, 2001 attacks|September 11 Terrorist Attacks]].)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ntsb.gov/info/Flight%20_Path_%20Study_UA93.pdf |format=PDF|title=Flight Path Study - United Airlines Flight 93 |date=2002-02-19 |publisher=[[National Transportation Safety Board]] |accessdate=2008-08-24}}</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 624]]''' crashed on June 17, 1948 outside of [[Aristes, Pennsylvania]], killing all 4 crew and 39 passengers aboard.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = United Air Lines, Inc., Near Mt. Carmel, Pennsylvania, June 17, 1948 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = July 28, 1949 | id = File No. 1-0075-48 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=409%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-27 }}</ref>
* '''[[USAir Flight 427]]''' [[wikt:nosedive|nosedive]]d into the ground after takeoff when the rudder on the [[Boeing 737-300]] malfunctioned near [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|Pittsburgh]] on September 8, 1994. All 132 passengers and crew were killed on impact.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1999). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/1999/AAR9901.pdf "Aircraft Accident Report: Uncontrolled Descent and Collision with Terrain; USAir Flight 427; Boeing 737-300, N513AU; Near Aliquippa, Pennsylvania; September 8, 1994".]. Retrieved October 22, 2009.</ref> This is the third-highest death toll of any accident involving the Boeing 737-300.
* '''[[USAir Flight 499]]''' overran the runway when landing at [[Erie International Airport]] in [[Erie, Pennsylvania]] on February 21, 1986. There were no fatalities.
==Rhode Island== <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[US Airways Express Flight 3758]]''' airplane slid off runway while landing at [[T.F. Green Airport]] on December 16, 2007. The flight, carrying 31 passengers and 3 crew members from Philadelphia, slid off the runway after landing shortly before 5 p.m. No injuries were reported and assumed the incident was related to the weather.<ref>[http://www.projo.com/news/content/storm_act_2_12-17-07_OP89HL2_v23.298f2eb.html Jet slides off runway.]</ref>
== South Carolina == * '''[[Eastern Airlines Flight 45]]''' collided with a [[US Army Air Force]] [[A-26 Invader]] bomber over northeastern South Carolina on July 12, 1945. One civilian, and two military personnel died.
==South Dakota== <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[Ozark Air Lines Flight 650]]''' struck a snow plow while landing at [[Sioux Falls Regional Airport]] during a snowstorm on December 20, 1983. The driver of the snow plow was the only casualty.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1985). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR85-01.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: US Air, Inc., Flight 183; McDonnel Douglas DC9-31, N964VJ; Detroit Metropolitan Airport, Detroit, Michigan; June 13, 1984]. Retrieved May 25, 2009.</ref>
==Tennessee== <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED -->
* '''[[American Airlines Flight 2]]''' crashed into the [[Mississippi River]] on February 10, 1944, killing all 24 on board. The cause of the crash remains unknown.
* '''[[American Airlines Flight 63 (Flagship Missouri)|American Airlines Flight 63]]''' crashed after ice formed on the wings and propeller near [[Centerville, Tennessee]] on October 15, 1943.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = REPORT OF THE CIVIL AERONAUTICS BOARD on the Investigation of an Accident Involving Aircraft In Scheduled Air Carrier Operation | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = January 9, 1945 | id = File No. 4889-43 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=235%22 | accessdate = 2007-01-25 }}</ref>
* '''[[Delta Air Lines Flight 516]]''' crashed short of the runway while attempting to land at [[Chattanooga Metropolitan Airport]] on November 27, 1973. The cause was attributed to pilot error.
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 823]]''' crashed near [[Parrotsville, Tennessee]] after an uncontrollable fire broke out in the main cabin, killing all 39 passengers and crew on July 9, 1964.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19640709-0|title=United Airlines Flight 823|accessdate=2009-05-25}}</ref>
==Texas== * '''[[American Airlines Flight 157]]''' crashed during final approach to [[Dallas Love Field|Love Field]] in [[Dallas, Texas]] after the pilot lost control when an engine failed on November 29, 1949. 26 passengers and 2 flight attendants died.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Accident Investigation Report | booktitle = American Airlines, Inc. Dallas Tex November 29, 1949 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = August 30, 1950 | id = File No. 1-0120 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=451%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-27 }}</ref>
* '''[[Braniff Flight 38]]''' was hijacked on January 12, 1972 while enroute to [[Dallas Love Field]]. All passengers and crew were able to escape safely in Dallas, and the hijacker was arrested.
* '''[[Braniff Flight 352]]''' broke up in mid air and crashed near [[Dawson, Texas]] after flying into a severe [[thunderstorm]] on May 3, 1968. All 85 on board were killed.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1969). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR69-03.pdf Aircraft accident report: Braniff Airways, Inc., Lockheed L- 188, N9707C, near Dawson, Texas, May 3, 1968]. Retrieved May 27, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Braniff Flight 542]]''' disintegrated in mid-air near [[Buffalo, Texas]] on September 29, 1959. All 34 passengers and crew were killed.
* '''[[American Airlines Flight 910]]''' collided with a privately-owned [[Temco Swift]] on June 28, 1952 while on approach to [[Dallas Love Field]]. Both people on board the Swift were killed and the aircraft was destroyed; Flight 910 landed safely with no injuries or fatalities.
* '''[[Continental Airlines Flight 1760]]''' made a safe landing through low clouds at the wrong airport on May 11, 2007. The flight landed safely at [[NOLF Cabaniss Field]] in [[Corpus Christi, Texas]] instead of their destination [[Corpus Christi International Airport]], {{convert|5|nmi|km}} to the southeast.<ref>{{cite news|title=Two pilots grounded in mix-up|work=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|date=May 13, 1997|accessdate=May 6, 2009|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DM&p_theme=dm&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0ED3D91208A61901&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM}}</ref>
* '''[[Continental Express Flight 2574]]''' crashed on descent in [[Eagle Lake, Texas]], near Houston, on September 11, 1991.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1992). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR92-04.pdf Aircraft accident report: Britt Airways, Inc., d/b/a Continental Express Flight 2574 in-flight structural breakup EMB-120RT, N33701 Eagle Lake, Texas September 11, 1991]. Retrieved May 27, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Delta Air Lines Flight 191]]''' crashed upon landing in [[Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport]] in Dallas/Fort Worth on August 2, 1985.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1986). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR86-05.pdf Aircraft accident report: Delta Air Lines, Inc., Lockheed L- 1011-385-1, N726DA, Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport, Texas, August 2, 1985]. Retrieved May 27, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Delta Air Lines Flight 1141]]''' crashed after takeoff from Dallas-Fort Worth Airport in Dallas/Fort Worth on August 31, 1988.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1988). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR89-04.pdf Aircraft accident report: Delta Air Lines, Inc., Boeing 727- 232, N473DA, Dallas, Fort Worth International Airport, Texas, August 31, 1988]. Retrieved May 27, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Delta Air Lines Flight 9570]]''' crashed at the [[Greater Southwest International Airport]] in [[Fort Worth, Texas]] during a training flight on May 30, 1972.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1973). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR73-03.pdf Aircraft accident report: Delta Air Lines, Inc., McDonnell Douglas DC-9-14, N3305L, Greater Southwest International Airport, Fort Worth, Texas, May 30, 1972]. Retrieved May 27, 2009.</ref>
==Utah== <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[United Airlines Flight 227]]''' crashed short of the runway while attempting a scheduled landing at [[Salt Lake City International Airport]], [[Salt Lake City, Utah]] on November 11, 1965.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = United Air Lines, Inc. Boeing 727, N7030U Salt Lake City, Utah November 11, 1965 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = June 7, 1966 | id = File No. 1-0032 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=788%22 | accessdate = 2007-01-25 }}</ref>
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 608]]''' crashed on October 24, 1947 about {{convert|1.5|mi|km}} southeast of [[Bryce Canyon Airport]], killing all on board.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = United Air Lines, Inc. Bryce Canyon, Utah, October 24, 1947 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = February 3, 1948 | id = File No. 1-0097-47 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=386%22 | accessdate = 2007-01-25 }}</ref>
==Virginia== * '''[[American Airlines Flight 77]]''' was hijacked after takeoff from [[Washington Dulles International Airport|Dulles]] on [[September 11 Terrorist Attacks|September 11, 2001]]. Terrorists crashed the aircraft into [[The Pentagon]] in [[Arlington County, Virginia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ntsb.gov/info/AAL77_fdr.pdf |format=PDF|title=American Airlines Flight 77 FDR Report |publisher=National Transportation Safety Board |date=2002-01-31 |accessdate=2008-06-02}}</ref>
* '''[[Capital Airlines Flight 20]]''' crashed into a farm in [[Charles City County, Virginia]], on January 18, 1960, killing all 50 people on board.<ref>{{cite news |first= Irving|last= Wallace|authorlink= |author= |coauthors= |title= 50 Die as Airliner Crashes in Virginia|newspaper= The Lima News|location= Lima, Ohio|page= 1|date= 1960-01-19|accessdate=2009-09-13|url= http://www.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewerTags.aspx?img=16085591}}</ref>
* '''[[Eastwind Airlines Flight 517]]''' suffered an in-flight [[rudder]] malfunction on June 9, 1996. The pilot was able to regain control of the [[Boeing 737-200]], and the aircraft landed safely with only a single injury at [[Richmond International Airport]].
* '''[[Piedmont Airlines Flight 349]]''' crashed into [[Bucks Elbow Mountain]] near [[Crozet, Virginia]] on October 30, 1959, killing all three crewmembers and 23 of 24 passengers.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19591030-0|accessdate=2009-09-13|title=Piedmont Airlines Flight 349}}</ref>
* '''[[TWA Flight 514]]''' crashed into [[Mount Weather]] during descent to [[Washington Dulles International Airport|Dulles International]], on {{date|December 1, 1974}}.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1975). [http://voyager.db.erau.edu/cgi-bin/Pwebrecon.cgi?DB=local&CNT=50&BOOL1=all+of+these&FLD1=Keyword+Anywhere+(GKEY)&SAB1=aircraft%20accident%20report%20514 Aircraft accident Report: Trans World Airlines, Inc., Boeing 727-231, N54328, Berryville, Virginia, December 1, 1974]. Retrieved September 13, 2009.</ref>
==Washington== <!-- These are crashes that occurred in the STATE of Washington, NOT Washington DC --> <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[D. B. Cooper|Northwest Airlines Flight 305]]''' was hijacked by a man using the alias "D. B. Cooper" on November 24, 1971. Cooper ransomed the passengers for $200,000 and four parachutes, and then later jumped from the plane over Washington state. Cooper was never seen again, and the case remains the only unsolved US aircraft hijacking.
* '''[[Northwest Orient Airlines Flight 2]]''' ditched into [[Puget Sound]] just off the [[Seattle]] waterfront shortly after takeoff from the [[Seattle-Tacoma International Airport]] on April 2, 1956. All of those aboard survived the ditching and escaped the aircraft before it sank, but four passengers and one flight attendant subsequently died.<ref>{{cite conference | title = Aircraft Accident Report | booktitle = Northwest Airlines, Inc., Boeing 377, N 74608, In Puget Sound, Near Seattle, Washington, April 2, 1956 | publisher = Civil Aeronautics Board | date = November 9, 1956 | id = File No. 1-0051 | url = http://dotlibrary1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?browse&rn=619%22 | accessdate = 2009-05-25 }}</ref>
==West Virginia== <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[Southern Airways Flight 932]]''' crashed near [[Huntington-Tri-State/Milton Airport]] carrying the [[Marshall University]] [[Marshall Thundering Herd]] [[American football|football]] squad, killing all on board.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1972). [http://www.marshall.edu/library/speccoll/virtual_museum/Memorial/pdfs/NTSB-AAR-72-11.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Southern Airways, Inc. DC-9, N97S; Tri-State Airport; Huntington, West Virginia; November 14, 1970]. Retrieved May 25, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Southwest Airlines Flight 2294]]''' made an emergency landing at [[Yeager Airport]] in [[Charleston, West Virginia]] after structural damage led to rapid [[uncontrolled decompression|depressurization]] of the passenger cabin on July 13, 2009. There were no fatalities.
==Wisconsin== <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[Midwest Express Airlines Flight 105]]''' crashed just after takeoff from [[General Mitchell Airport]], [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]] on September 6, 1985 after suffering engine failure. All on board died during impact or in the post-crash fire.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1987). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/1987/AAR8701.htm "Aircraft Accident Report: Midwest Express Airlines, INC., DC-9-14, N100ME; General Billy Mitchell Field Milwaukee, Wisconsin; September 6, 1985" (summary)]. Retrieved May 25, 2009.</ref> * '''[[Northwest Airlines Flight 421]]''' crashed near the Wisconsin-Minnesota border after flying into a thunderstorm on {{date|August 29, 1948}}. It was the first loss of a [[Martin 2-0-2]] aircraft, and the worst disaster involving a Martin 2-0-2 to date.<ref>[[Civil Aeronautics Board]]. Docket #SA-178. File #1-0117. June 29, 1949. [http://ntl1.specialcollection.net/scripts/ws.dll?file&fn=8&name=*S%3A%5CDOT_56GB%5Cairplane%20accidents%5Cwebsearch%5C082948.pdf pdf]. [[US Department of Transportation]]. Accessed online on September 7, 2009.</ref>
==Wyoming== <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[United Airlines Cheyenne Crash|United Airlines Trip 4]]''' crashed near [[Silver Crown, Wyoming]] on October 7, 1935. The Bureau of Air Commerce determined the cause was pilot error. All 12 aboard perished.
* '''[[United Airlines Flight 409]]''' crashed into [[Medicine Bow Peak]], near [[Centennial, Wyoming]], on October 6, 1955, killing all 66 people on board. At the time, this was the worst crash in U.S. commercial aviation history.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19551006-0|accessdate=2009-05-25|title=United Airlines Flight 409}}</ref>
* '''[[Western Airlines Flight 470]]''' overran the runway at [[Casper/Natrona County International Airport]] on March 31, 1975. All 99 people on board the aircraft survived.
== U.S. Territories == ===American Samoa=== <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[Pan Am Flight 806]]''' crashed on approach to [[Pago Pago International Airport]] on January 30, 1974, killing all 97 people on board.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1977). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR77-07.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Pan American World Airways, Inc.; Boeing 707-3215, NK54A; Pago Pago, American Samoa; January 30, 1974]. Retrieved May 25, 2009</ref> * The '''[[Samoan Clipper]]''', one of ten [[Pan American Airways]] [[Sikorsky S-42]] [[flying boat]]s, exploded over [[Pago Pago, American Samoa]] on January 11, 1938.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzhistory.net.nz/timeline&new_date=2/1|title=Today in History: NZHistory.net.nz, New Zealand history online|accessdate=2009-05-25}}</ref>
=== Guam (United States) === <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[Korean Air Flight 801]]''' crashed on {{date|August 6, 1997}} on approach to [[Antonio B. Won Pat International Airport]], Guam.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (2000). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/2000/AAR0001.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Controlled Flight into Terrain; Korean Air Flight 801; Boeing 747-300, HL7468; Nimitz Hill, Guam; August 6, 1997]. Retrieved May 25, 2009</ref> 228 of the 254 people aboard the [[Boeing 747]] perished in the crash. It is the deadliest crash in Guam to date, and the 9th deadliest crash involving a 747.<ref>{{ASN accident|id=19970806-0|accessdate= 2009-11-14|title="Korean Air Flight 801}}</ref>
===Puerto Rico=== <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[American Eagle Flight 5401]]''' crashed while landing in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]] on May 9, 2004.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (2005). [http://www.ntsb.gov/publictn/2005/AAR0502.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Crash During Landing; Executive Airlines (doing business as American Eagle) Flight 5401; Avions de Transport Regional 72-212, N438AT; San Juan, Puerto Rico; May 9, 2004]. Retrieved May 25, 2009.</ref>
* '''[[Prinair Flight 191]]''' crashed while attempting to land at [[Mercedita Airport]] on June 24, 1972. Five people died in the accident.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1975). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR75-17.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: Puerto Rico International Airlines (Prinair), Inc.; DeHavilland DH-114, N554PR; Ponce, Puerto Rico; June 24, 1972]. Retrieved May 25, 2009.</ref>
===U.S. Virgin Islands=== <!-- List items WITHOUT dedicated articles on Wikipedia WILL BE DELETED --> * '''[[American Airlines Flight 625]]''' crashed at [[St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands]] on April 27, 1976 due to pilot error. 37 people on board perished.<ref>National Transportation Safety Board (1976). [http://libraryonline.erau.edu/online-full-text/ntsb/aircraft-accident-reports/AAR77-01.pdf Aircraft Accident Report: American Airlines, Inc.; Boeing 727-95, N1963; St. Thomas, Virgin Islands; April 27, 1976]. Retrieved May 25, 2009.</ref>
